body:
Here's a hunch: what you do you get from:

```
python -c 'import select; print(select.__file__)'
```

 when you are seeing this?

```
$ python -c 'import select; print(select.__file__)'
/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/lib-dynload/select.so
```

That's from the Bash terminal, not inside IPython. Not sure which you were suggesting. I can't do anything when I call `ipython` because that error pops up and the kernel freezes. Control-C won't get me out of it, so I just have to close the terminal window.
Hm. Is there a `select.py` or `select/` directory anywhere you can find? I'm guessing the error is due to something being imported instead of the stdlib module.

I ran across something similar recently, where a conda installation and a pip installation of prompt_toolkit had clashed and produced a broken result. Some version of PT had a `select.py` in that folder, and some other version had an `import select`, which wound up doing relative import on Python 2.

Try uninstalling `prompt_toolkit` entirely (whatever it's called in macports), and reinstalling. If it still doesn't work, uninstall both IPython and prompt_toolkit with macports, and then use pip to install them:

```
pip install --upgrade setuptools pip
pip install ipython
```

@minrk yes, I found a file select.py. Three of them, in fact:

```
[13][11:19:50][dbrowne][/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7] find ./ -name "select.py"
.//site-packages/prompt_toolkit/eventloop/select.py
.//site-packages/tornado/platform/select.py
.//site-packages/zmq/backend/select.py
```

I thought that namespaces were a honking great idea and we should do more of them, haha. Can't imagine why people would develop a module with the same name as a stdlib module.

My environment setup is a big mess honestly, because I started installing packages through either MacPorts or pip when I was still a total Python noob. It wasn't pretty, but it worked, so I never bothered to clean it up. I've considered switching to something like Homebrew, but I find the idea of uninstalling everything rather daunting.

@takluyver I followed your suggestion of uninstalling and reinstalling PT/IPython and that did the trick! Though it took a couple of tries for some reason...


Thank you both very much for the help!!!
